comments.commentBody:
Re: Arsenal never quite making it. There is a philosophical divide here. Arsenal in the last decade or so have been paying off a new stadium with a policy of paying for what you buy (low net spend) in an age when massive sugar daddies from Russia and Abu Dhabi appeared. They've done OK, and despite a rash of "Wenger Out!" cries (now silent) their large global fanbase seems to support that.

In addition they have a persistent injury problem that can't just be bad luck (they're doing something wrong) and until recently a certain tactical inflexibility and preference for style over grit and guts. Their recent success is a combination of the Emirates payoff being under control (allowing the signings of the likes of Ozil and Sanchez) and newfound tactical flexibility (they've been playing the counter a lot, but they're also the only ones to have run Leicester City off the pitch). Giroud and Kosc are stepping up, Bellerin and Coq are coming into their own, and it looks like Campbell will too.

As for Leicester, what an amazing story. They barely hung on, lost Cambiasso, lost Pearson, and look at them now. One could be a pessimist and note that we're only 17 games out of 38, that the slog gets hard late in the winter, that Vardy, Mahrez, and Kante are logging a lot of miles and they'll have to continue that form for another 21 matches. But even if they don't win it all they've massively overachieved. They'll be in Europe for sure next year.

Apples to oranges.  Draupadi marrying 5 men won't kill you--at its worst that can encourage polyandry in some sect that takes Draupadi's life choices literally and as applicable today.  But jihad is a different beast, my friend.  If jihad requires that Islam's soldiers must fight for the imposition of Islam on all infidels and apostates, that must be expunged or disowned or reformed or relegated to the boondocks.
Then I insist you travel to land occupied by Isis in order to quell them of their troubles.  Good luck!!!

Again and again, we hear how the personal stories of terrorists are really individuals who come from troubled unbalanced upbringing and latching onto the "Muslim Terrorist" bandwagon to express their rage. How is this "political"? These are troubled individuals who need real help to find real balance, real peace, real self-understanding and real hope to live a better life. It is easy to forget something so obvious staring at us in the eye ball. I do not see a religious fanatic, a political zealot, I see a troubled man.

Where do you gather your knowledge from, RSS ?
Let me enlighten you
Women r allowed to pray in mosques in separate section so as to avoid distraction....but I do wonder why Hindu women are not allowed in ayyapa temple or sc,st in any other upper class temples ??? Getting married of early is cultural as that is prevalent not just where u pointed out but among Indians /subcontinent all religions alike...I am worried about not just Nigerian sexual enslavement of any girls but across the world ....be it the Eve teasing (how Hindus call sexual harassment as) in rape country of the world(India???) or child marriages in Rajasthan/central india.
I don't want to respond further so before you write something, think if the problem is religious or political or cultural.
The bud is now a bloom.  On this advice of nipping in the bud you're a bit late.

I had an almost similar experience with my mother 2 years ago - If I had not been a Geriatric Care Manager now called Aging Life Care Experts her end of life would not have been with the dignity that all of us deserve. I truly support a Medicare Part Q and would hope that whom ever is in charge of putting such a plan into place for us mortals still living I hope they use skilled care managers with advance degrees in Health and Human resources - VillagePlan or Aging Life Care Association are resources to find such.

My mom went to the hospital 8 times in one year and every time a hospitalist changed her medications and things got worse. Finally I brought in Hospice and things settled down - but I had to get her out of the skilled nursing center that cost $10,000 a month and find a small group home where she was not left to languish in her bed looking like she was already dead. In the small home I found she was dressed with makeup on and up every day doing exercises and socializing in group activities - yes she was dying and we had Hospice overseeing her care - but she lived till she died at age 92 with dignity. The very night before she died she asked the care provider to take her to the room of each person (5 others) and say, "goodnight" - she had never done that before. Good ends of life can be found and had - all deserve them!

After having suffered through the death of my elderly father and the maddening carnival ride that is Medicare today, and the patchwork services it offers the very elderly, where it seems no provider has a clue about what the other has done, prescribed, diagnosed etc. and the comfort of the patient is seemingly of negligible concern ... All I can say is it was shameful to treat the man that way.  He was a good American citizen.  He fought with the 101st Airborne Division in Belgium and across central Europe in his teens! mustering out with a Bronze Star at the end of the war.  He got an education on the GI Bill and was a Forestry professor for over 40 years, teaching young foresters from America and around the world.  He deserved better, we all deserve better.  Ms. Katy Butler is right on the money, I can't say how much I wish we had had a Part Q to ease my father's death, for him and for us.

The question is who decides who owes.

You owe me.

Pay up.

Not fair? If you check your bank account tomorrow and find my lawyer has garnished it, you know who Mr Call feels. It's called due process.

I read an autobiography of a mob guy who was always looking for a way to get set up in a cash business so that he could have, "a license to steal', because cash could be taken before it was recorded in the books. Well these binding arbitration clauses in business contracts really are a license to steal. As long as a business preys on people who cannot afford to act on behalf of their rights, the courts happily give them permission to take the money and run. It's really an example of where people can only have justice if they have the money to buy it.
That's just what they hope you will do. Once you make such an agreement, a time barred debt becomes "fresh" again.

Under certain circumstances, a debt arbitration can be moved to a courtroom.

I had to take my 14-year-old once to an arbitration hearing for a large debt that was not his, but was in his name. Since he was a minor, as his parent I was allowed to speak for him. The attorney representing the collections company failed to appear.

The clerk and other attorneys who had cases that day in arbitration seemed amused by our situation. The clerk mentioned, perhaps nudged .... (note: always take heed when a court clerk shares insider wisdom!) ..... that I could request the case be heard before a judge - and said that the judge was in his courtroom and available.

So with the consent of all parties present (namely my son and myself), the case was immediately listed for trial and my son got his audience with the judge who then issued his decision: "non pros". The insufferable debt collector filed no further motions.

Now that some years have passed, and there haven't been any new cases listed under my son's name, I had assumed the matter was finished. But will the debt collectors try to come after my son again once he is grown up? Beware the arbitration bogeymen!

Listen up, you have 30 days to order cease and desist letter back to them. I filed a letter.  The old debt was not mine to begin with.  It was for long distance phone service in a state I use to live in.  I did not sign for the utilities.  The debt collecting company was trying to re-age the debt. The statute of limitations was more than run out.  I then filed a letter to the State Licensing department, warning them of this type of business practice going on in their state.  I had to deal with them two times, they had a host of subsidiaries that came at me.  I called the Carrier and verified that I never had long distance and my name was in good standing with them.  Protect yourselves, anything does happen. I lived this in 2011.

So, you're advocating a system where bought and paid for "Justices" allow unscrupulous greed-driven predators to use the court system to confiscate the bank accounts of innocent American citizens without notice, and those same American citizens CANNOT use the court system to defend themselves? Is that your vision of fairness, Josh? Is that your vision of Democracy? Is that your vision of Free Market Capitalism?

Say it isn't so, Sir...

What about New York's General Business law that prohibits unconscionable business practices? And federal mail fraud statutes?

How about criminal fraud and larceny prosecutions?

Wrong. I paid my premium, but got caught in a fight with my insurance company over a bill they agreed to pay and then reneged on. By the time I realized what was going on, which was that the hospital was going to sell my debt while I was still in limbo with the insurance company, I was stuck, with no recourse.

These stories infuriate me.  On the other hand who should we be contacting directly to put pressure on for change?  Our congressman?  Certain senators?  I wish the Times would include a follow up section but maybe that would make it  seem too bias - towards citizens.

I agree with all you say and do live simply, but I was trapped by an unavoidable medical expense the insurance company said they would pay and didn't. I live a very healthy lifestyle, but sometimes things happen. I also wonder if poorer zip codes are targeted by these firms, exactly the places where simpler living people often chose to go?

Citibank recently sent me a notice amending by general type of account  name (no account numbers) any agreements I have with them. The amendment replaced my ability to take them to court to defend myself or sue them with a complicated arbitration process which also precluded me from filing a class action suit. I had 30 days to opt out and they provided the exact wording to use to do this. I immediately opted out with their precise wording and requested an acknowledgement that I followed their instructions and had opted out. Just received a letter back from them indicating they could not respond because I did not include my account numbers which they did not ask for nor include in their original letter to me. What kind of shenanigans is this?

Oddly, that is not what I said.  I object to a second buyer being able to put you into a situation where you may not be able to defend yourself against them without undue financial hardship.  I had a medical billing the was false, but I was out of the country and did not receive any notification until it had destroyed my credit rating. To fight that now that it went to 'collections' I found the original medical biller will not get involved and left me the hands, while out of the country, against a secondary company filing against me in court where I received no notification except when it showed up on y credit report and it was too late.
Seriously? Rights are being violated, the same rights granted to you and yours. Wake up, judges are taking the easy road out from a heavy case load.
Mandatory arbitration should be against the law. No one should be able to sign away their rights.
Hilarious. Saved it.

John,

I believe you gave too much of a preveal tonight. I didn't even have to guess. This guy was big on Christmas songs. You might say he is a ghost of Christmas past.

You are wrong. Regulating the problem is easy if you are not corrupt, in the pocket of special interest lobbyists, or a political hack. You just make everyone involved have skin in the game and in the end confiscate the assets of those above. Get the incentives and the disincentive right.

I recently left earbuds in accidentally during a quick visit to the grocery store. I realized after the fact that it was my first retail experience without annoying Christmas ear worms in weeks - perhaps months.

Anecdotally, my 19 year old son uses headphones as a "do not disturb" indicator with gusto - especially when trapped in the car with a parent. He's often not listening to music but makes the show of pulling out the earbuds and asking for comments to be repeated.

I love head phones and have been wearing them since I received my first Walkman in the mid 90s. My parents who argued a lot and had a tendency to speak at me hated them.

I have a strong feeling that many of those "disturbed" by people's decision to tune out are the same kinds of people who felt their social status entitled them to speak AT me as a young person or as a female.

Are there lots of rude people in the world? Yes. Perhaps that is why so many have chosen to signal, "No thanks" in being approached in public or when working.
